72C16B9012A5456D8066FB7BF2A00A38.description: Establish a plan for lifelong participation in dance or movement

E16094E9F4754CC49F353AEA135E4757.description: Explore a dance/movement opportunity one might pursue in one’s own life.

0898B99E156B43A7B1F57C565004D7EB.description: Discuss transferable skills learned from dance to the career students are interested in pursuing.

AD4B2AA6191D4E498E6411B9A9477D42.description: Investigate and identify careers that would suit one’s strengths, beliefs and interests

C97EB44084964B0EA67B02D18C3991A8.description: Analyze and explore ways that skills and competencies learned from dance apply to careers one is interested in pursuing.

07278A97452A42F982B47580F37FED3A.description: Investigate why certain dance compositions were considered to be controversial at different times in Canadian history.

6CEA6C35402E4166B0520EDE2D63F9CD.description: Pose questions about how different belief systems view dance (e.g., repression, affirmation).

62DF39FB4C03441ABACB330EEE7A5528.description: Investigate the role of dance within Indigenous societies across Canada, specifically precontact and post-colonial.

5FFD1FCE009A4C4981822CFD6E9DACC8.description: Examine dance rituals and ceremonies in a variety of Canadian belief systems.

345E18DC7F3B4C02A83DE9BF7212390A.description: Investigate choreographers as activists throughout history, and identify how own dance composition relates to these ideas.

EBE7A28F9D354145B5A62D8626634D61.description: Investigate the synergies and evolutions of dance in response to current cultural globalization.

B0950BE442DA499A9408543C89633672.description: Describe the significance of the evolution of dance types, styles and specific choreography throughout history and discuss how the work is connected to social activism.

4E154FBB1F90411B8AC5F486480C7DA6.description: Analyze how social messages are communicated through time, identify what makes them memorable and use this information in own work.

1EF866797D8E422BAC1D64859833CBF7.description: Develop understanding of dance within a Canadian historical context.

819ECE5A7C034D4D9B28610A514438FC.description: Describe how dance can transmit or question values and beliefs.

9B3BD9F485C540E99FC61DCCF634CD33.description: Use social commentary in a way that reflects the idea of a professional artist.

96961551B3B842EF89212AC958CBD52C.description: Investigate choreographers’ approaches to creating social activism

CA4045236EB84705A8C7256048E0D5D0.description: Examine choreography that is reflective of social commentary and make connections with development of own work.

84C2D77F62E849CC895F32DFFE85B98B.description: Examine choreographers who investigate specific social ideas through dance.

D5DA162481C6482CB739032B6AECB9E0.description: Develop understanding of dance within a Canadian social context

C0D33637BC2B4235AFB4414B6CF25515.description: Conduct research (e.g., digital, live, interview) on a contemporary First Nation, Inuit or Métis dancer or dance maker in Canada and report on such things as: philosophy or focus, subject or themes presented, discipline specific or interdisciplinary work, and the potential influence of traditional practices (e.g., ask questions such as Do traditional practices and/or Elders influence the work you create? Does your culture influence the subject matter or themes of your work?)

2E5A986513994307832B39BC6349B2E9.description: Examine topics related to gender and sexual diversity (e.g., two-spirit individuals) in dance.

B3E1CEE7F3214EB296B0ED178B96C46E.description: Examine topics related to gender and sexual diversity (e.g., two-spirit individuals) in dance.

95BA79F9460344A2B5FC012FE0D2161F.description: Examine topics related to gender and sexual diversity (e.g., two-spirit individuals) in dance.

3C851B8B06F143449E8D30A1288BA645.description: Examine protocols related to the teaching, learning and presenting of dances of Saskatchewan and other Canadian Indigenous peoples.

DA685A8A0129447880A48C0AC340717F.description: Conduct an inquiry into how Saskatchewan and other Canadian Indigenous peoples’ experiences and worldviews are expressed through dance

F7253D80DB214A61995022B4AD6EA582.description: Examine how dance and dance makers influence and respond to social, political and cultural contexts.

E1331CD88B9C42E19041A0BADD27A19D.description: Analyze how the work of contemporary and traditional First Nations dances and dance makers (e.g., Michael Greyeyes, Floyd Favel Starr) and Métis dances and dance makers (e.g., Scott Duffee, Krystle Pederson) are influenced by relationships to land, tradition, community and impacts of colonization (e.g., Truth, Dance and Reconciliation documentary, treaty education outcome SI12 -investigate the values and beliefs of self, family, community, and society in relation to the importance of honouring the Spirit and Intent of treaties).

E39E5B95B7664E1FA25667F51D25132F.description: Discuss the ways of knowing and learning (e.g., dances passed down/gifted) that are applied to learning traditional and contemporary First Nations and Métis dances.

E11C10E53F44498CB90A314675D0C9E5.description: Examine Indigenous perspectives on traditional and contemporary dance, drawing where possible/appropriate on the experience of students and expertise community members.

49732C5CDABA457BB4B924E9294FD025.description: Engage, digitally or in-person, with Indigenous Elders, Knowledge Keepers, community leaders and/or dancers to understand the impact of Indigenous practices and perspectives related to dance making.

E4A9EC0EA093483C8527421246487D11.description: Investigate how Indigenous perspectives and ways of knowing, including local cultural knowledge, impact the creation of traditional and contemporary dance.

92766B37B23F40BB973C526792C43E62.description: Cultural/Historical (CH) Goal: Students will investigate the content and aesthetics of the arts within cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts, and understand the connection between the arts and the human experience.

7F9860405DE64A129617C53893C27002.description: Debate and/or discuss questions surrounding appropriation (e.g., When does portrayal cross the line into perpetuating stereotypes? Who can participate in culture-specific dances? When does borrowing become cultural appropriation in dance? When can culturally specific elements such as regalia designs be incorporated in dance? Is hip hop dancing cultural appropriation?).

F0EE4CA9FA904C6EB39E77678D4C1C30.description: Survey students, community members and artists regarding their perspectives on the issues.

3C7FD15748B64E9E967C8AF1629C7F1D.description: Research examples of controversy in dance and the arts regarding appropriation.

2B9FDFF2F3B64C8C9D2CC02ADAB7BBDC.description: Generate questions concerning appropriation of voice in dance and the arts.

A04AAA60561F4B2595C397CFD3FCF6CA.description: Conduct an inquiry into the boundaries of cultural appropriation (e.g., what dances and/or elements of dances are appropriate?).

E129C32026E64B3A99B766176758182B.description: Examine the issues, questions and concerns of appropriation of voice in dance and the arts.

992D0A4FA73744049BB97B355AE34B7E.description: Take part in, analyze and respond to dances that reflect Canadian social, environmental and/or political issues.

5375A4A034794210A3B8371B84D7ADEC.description: View, analyze and respond to dances that reflect Canadian social, environmental and/or political issues.

933C7854927F4F59AB797B452DEA4284.description: Transfer understanding of a dance maker’s work related to a Canadian social, environmental and/or political issue into own dance compositions.

EF266D8230CC4521B966C33712BE4CC1.description: Research and reflect on ways that dance raises awareness, challenges thinking and inspires change with regard to issues such as treaty rights, land usage, immigration, diversity, war, ethics, human rights, water rights, disease, racism, gender and sexual diversity, suicide.

7024DC85C287462BA1420E1032C94629.description: Compare personal and collective thinking, perspectives and biases about societal issues before and after viewing and responding to dance.

E2AA9CB26977423687E0165495E77C78.description: Examine Canadian social, environmental and political issues and their influence on current dance compositions (e.g., dance as social or political commentary).

5326422769674F2785FFF6AFA6C51F1A.description: Analyze how dance challenges and influences personal and collective thinking about Canadian social, environmental and/or political issues.

B84A85A7A6C34F869DEE157ED065CEC0.description: Identify potential for extended growth or future work based on feedback from self, peers and others (e.g., guest dancer/choreographer).

CA0BD1CED2D14B48AE6B1E11EF70D888.description: Respond to dance compositions on an emotional, associative and formal intellectual level.

34174E376AD044958E8470649B74BD2D.description: Using a framework appropriate to the dance type and style, assess dance compositions (e.g., footwork in Fancy dance, movement of roach in Grass dance, isolations in hip hop, use of turnout in ballet).

1005534AB3204A45BEF16B926C2A7190.description: Critique own, peers’ and others’ dance compositions, in progress and finished, identifying and articulating strengths and areas for improvement.

74E7E9B6FD34442B9534BB38C290CA0F.description: Seek and apply feedback from others during dance-making process.

B94070B912C84DCE901018D4873FCEDD.description: Provide rationale for contextual and environmental production decisions (e.g., lighting, staging, sets, props in a theatre; site-specific permits, safety considerations, sound, technical requirements).

88575C61A92F495A815DFB83F1C04EDC.description: Articulate goals and intentions for dance, using discipline-specific terminology.

3EF3EA17F60C4B10B038DE5DCF7D3508.description: Identify and organize criteria, individually or collectively-developed, to analyze and assess dance compositions.

A605CCDAEC0B4316AAC90ADC1B728270.description: Respond critically and constructively to dance compositions, in progress and complete, using terminology and rationale specific to the dance type and style.

002EA9E31CD24DBBAF63F31CC6FEA134.description: Take personal risks in developing and sharing dance work.

77EE201C5285487AB86621C92D4D6225.description: Analyze how own dance can address larger questions of human existence and perspectives (e.g., identity-related inquiry questions such as Who built me? Where am I from? Where am I going? What is my purpose? What is my self-worth?).

FFF2C83864F949B290C6AB33B0176818.description: Reflect on how dance has created a sense of community in the classroom, school, local and national community (e.g., powwow, hip hop, Ukrainian communities).

F1F6CBE712144F899C509C785C2C8721.description: Provide evidence of active and critical engagement in community through dance.

8DA30A5871244E24B4E9901DA097DF63.description: Use dance to promote compassion and empathy for the human experience

A76DE0310AE44995883DB6C2CF2753DE.description: Connect and apply training methods and practices (e.g., medicine wheel, wellness wheel, sports medicine, somatic practices/Pilates) to promote mental and physical health and wellbeing.

3658526FC3AD456A9A3E9D7329BF8410.description: Identify and research (e.g., interview) Canadians whose lives and work inspires own dance expressions, interpretations and/or dance making.

3428B672D8CE4AFF8AB9042A3EA63001.description: Demonstrate leadership (e.g., lead dance class for lower grade level, plan seniors’ centre movement class) in developing and sharing dance work.

F1834413B87B409CBD70968EFC7EE771.description: Reflect on and articulate how dance impacts student voice in relation to the world.

39F9FF9086504A6CBD5227AD138BFCCD.description: Establish mindful and/or contemplative exercises (e.g., written reflection, video, blog) as a daily dance practice.

494E4C5593644085BACF0301426CCE13.description: Reflect on how dance has impacted one’s life (e.g., growth, perspective, agency, relationship to world, cultural identity, personal experience).

3767E6233CA94F4A8978AE9D36B022A4.description: Examine how dance deepens one’s insight into self and expands relationship with community.

E046FA1ACDE147CCA6924B472EEDA557.description: Critical/Responsive (CR) Goal: Students will respond to artistic expressions of Saskatchewan, Canadian, and International artists using critical thinking, research, creativity, and collaborative inquiry.

5A7C814080AD4DA6975145BB39253FCD.description: Apply peer and teacher feedback during rehearsal process to improve performance.

8F48472F2B994726933041027B51F14F.description: Demonstrate one’s optimal level of physical and artistic abilities when dancing.

AD64D3FF766146B28EE54145CFC4DC6A.description: Rehearse and refine composition to convey the dance maker’s vision.

78E3F2EE58DF47FD857B71B70A152548.description: Collaborate, problem solve and communicate clearly during rehearsal and dance performance (e.g., making adjustments in the moment, dealing with unforeseen technical difficulties).

F90BC69EAFB04883AA67D00A84A5D873.description: Perform dances inspired by the work of recognized Canadian dance makers.

34C1A4E1CF2841079FF246DBEDD468DC.description: Perform movement or dance composition that has a focus on social justice (e.g., reconciliation) and cultural diversity in a Canadian context.

B1666C34D9A643B08CD09C88BADD9D31.description: Perform movement or dance composition to convey personal experience.

E8A6EF9D5C3F44E9B0B9AD0E8B50EB5E.description: Perform solo, duo or group dances that convey personal vision or social commentary.

594A21622A934163ACF176F365E3828F.description: Keep a record of dance-making ideas and choreography using traditional or invented notation.

B307522C2B0A4EE887AC4DEF16D7BADC.description: Collaborate and demonstrate leadership with peers, teacher, community members during dance-making process.

E8E4F1A042BD43B4860F9B2D4D6910FD.description: Design overall vision including production components such as space, attire/regalia, lighting, sound, set and props, working with a range of resources (e.g., found objects).

0AF1DF2518FF40D28BEF3F67182DCE27.description: Demonstrate collaboration, problem solving and clear communication during the dancemaking process.

FF98DAA0E5C04ADDACD7E14F3379A631.description: Adapt choreography for a range of abilities.

3790B8F20F124497B403FDF80FA8FF8A.description: Create dance with a focus on social justice (e.g., reconciliation) and cultural diversity in a Canadian context.

C318F9A91C3B4AA4987770616E1C69A2.description: Incorporate a Canadian dance maker’s (e.g., Michael Greyeyes, Robin Poitras, Peggy Baker) ideas and movement style into a dance composition.

30500D471ADB4D47931AEB7F5A4671CA.description: Research Canadian choreographers’ methods and practices.

F0E750B0ADBF4F7C89709A66A96AE694.description: Demonstrate purposeful use of dance elements and choreographic form in dance-making process.

0BFA5D68B95144EAACD81DC13E064A42.description: Use another art form (e.g., drama, visual art, music) or discipline (e.g., science, social studies, physical education) as inspiration for dance making.

978ADDB8D72948409C135EFC2930EAF3.description: Create movement or dance composition inspired by personal experience, social issue or recognized Canadian dance maker.

2609DC852559441C9F1D16AE815631E6.description: Create solo, duo or group dances that convey personal vision or social commentary.

7C8743B935864116B5A2B87E81CBF2A6.description: Execute technique with precision in all dance types and styles studied.

62150FAABB504122A30466FC8D58C58D.description: Explore Métis dances as forms of artistic expression and social connection in communities and research competitive dance (e.g., square dance clothing designs, Métis sash colours and designs and their meaning, the number of changes that can be done).

8ED2BAC6A5C146AA8224AAD7A0D410F4.description: Demonstrate knowledge of techniques and protocols associated with First Nations dances.

99544AC9D04942AD837FA2B9A9569DC1.description: Integrate technique associated with different dance types and styles to create new work.

E9E60C00C27C473C98D97835FBD9D32F.description: Apply, independently, body alignment specific to the selected dance type and style (e.g., Métis dance type including jigging or square dance styles, hip hop dance type including breaking or locking styles; powwow dance type including Grass or Fancy dance styles).

BEF7E4897A1042B5A32D12BA15CB8DF9.description: Embody elements of dance and adapt to the changes and complexities of the dance making process.

6B897036E53A432BA9E3147498D9C499.description: Demonstrate body and spatial awareness while executing dance technique.

1948BAA5567F4F12942F93901339F623.description: Implement and lead warm-up and cool-down in dance class.

BC5B4A4B223746658A2A36D79626DAD0.description: Apply, independently, technique and strategies for safe execution of dance movements (e.g., lifts).

693AF34D39F04D558BAA364D2B00F6E0.description: Refine and integrate the dance techniques needed to perform a particular dance type and style (e.g., ballroom as a type of dance including waltz, foxtrot or tango styles; ballet as a type of dance including classical or contemporary styles; powwow as a type of dance including grass or fancy styles; modern as a type of dance including Graham or contact improvisation styles; Indian classical type of dance including Bharatanatyam Kathak or Kathakali styles).

4BE7B9E63A1D4616AF0F0102CEB44230.description: Investigate and demonstrate dance technique and related protocols within a range of cultural contexts, including First Nations and Métis.

ACCCC1D215BA405A864C6880BECCA2AF.description: Creative/Productive (CP) Goal: Students will inquire, create, and communicate through dance, drama, music and visual art.
